headline: Great for experience
pros: A good job for gaining experience. Outside of your typical duties you’ll have limited exposure to clients. The culture is focused on pushing workers to perform at a high level. We’re well supported by all levels of management. Drinking beers on Friday helps to build camaraderie with co-workers.
cons: The long hours are the biggest con.

headline: Not perfect but striving to do better
pros: Not a perfect company by any means. We’ve had our struggles with morale and turnover. The coronavirus hasn’t made these issues any easier. However, AME Group has proven many times over that they’re willing to work on their faults and support their staff to provide a work environment that’s dedicated to their personal and professional growth. Though not perfect, their hearts are in the right place and that’s all that matters to me.
cons: You can look at the other reviews if you want an idea of the cons we’ve struggled with. I see improvements constantly and can only hope and pray that we continue to strive to do better as a company.

headline: An amazing company
pros: If you’re willing and able to invest your energy into working at AME you won’t be sorry. You get an in-depth look into the mining industry that most people don’t get to typically see. Management is always a pleasure to work with. They expect you to work hard, so as long as you’re doing your job and pulling your weight you shouldn’t encounter any problems.
cons: This is a high-pressure environment that will eventually begin to wear on you.
advice_to_mgmt: Ignore the naysayers. Continue to strive towards the future and do right by your employees.

headline: Management should be embarrassed. Fraudulent. Shockingly low benchmark for work quality. Horrible treatment of staff.
status:
8 December 2019
Helpful (19)
"Management should be embarrassed. Fraudulent. Shockingly low benchmark for work quality. Horrible treatment of staff."
1.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros: The fact that I can write this review and empathise with what others have written here. Years later I still think back to how terribly run the business was/is (clearly still the case based on what is written here).
cons:
Shaun Browne is a pathalogical liar. His word is worthless. Not only does he completely overstate his own experience and knowledge base but he must be deluded, regarding AME's standing in the industry. 

Any time an actually knowledgable or competent staff member (very few of these as all AME does is hire, and then overwork/underpay inexperienced staff), proposed (or heaven forbid proactively pursued) real anaysis Shaun would reject the suggestion.....borne out of ego and a deep mistrust for his staff. 

In my time since work at AME (approx 5yrs ago) I have gone on to work in other commoditiy based business and EVERY person I have ever spoken about having worked at AME either A) laughed and we shared stories about the time they worked there to or B) they expressed genuine disbelief at how poor the work from AME is

I laugh now whenever I see material from AME in my day to day. Many times I have actively recommended businesses I am associated with NOT to use AME simply due to its exceptionally poor standard of work.

It is amazing to me the company still has clients. The level of useful, insightful analysis behind the work is shockingly low and out of date. The number of times embarrassing errors were pointed out by clients was endless.
advice_to_mgmt:
Read these review. Take it on board. Maybe aim for some self improvement. They are written by honest, smart people that you treated poorly. Your reputation in the industry is permantently damaged. 

And how funny are the comments being posted to these reviews? Nothing more clearly demonstrates the management's mind set than the feeble attempts to discredit what a clearly genuine experiences.

headline: Strange
pros: They pay you and you get to see the other side of the mining industry that you wouldn’t see as a mining professional, I was lucky enough not to be subjected to some of the behaviour from upper management that has been written about in other reviews. The other technical staff were quite helpful and easy to get along with.
cons: While I got along with most of the colleagues at this place there is this underlying tension here that you’d have to cut with a steak knife it’s so thick. The chief is probably one of the most paranoid people I’ve ever worked for, there was a security camera on my floor that was watching people while they worked, which is illegal by the way. I also noticed that one of the administrators would go around to peoples desks and do a kinda roll call making sure everyone was at work, kinda like being back in primary school. Not allowed to send external emails as well which I found strange.
advice_to_mgmt: I can totally understand that you need to protect your intellectual property in order to run this business however I have serious concerns about the mental health of upper management due to the strange behaviour that I witnessed while working here. A corporate psychologist would have a field day with AME.

headline: Career destroyer! Think twice before joining.

cons:
1. Micro-management - half hourly timesheet to fill everyday
2. Workload - expect you to work crazy hour and it's called becoming an expert so you should do this for free
3. Resource - lacking and shocking! Each analyst is doing 2/3 people workload. 
4. Career progression - none unless you can make money for the company.
5. Over promised - always yes to clients even though it is not deliverables. Creative thinking is highly desireable and rewarded!
6. Holiday - 2-3 week compulsory holidays (depend which regional office) over Xmas when it is the quietest period. What can I say? Just do not expect holiday any other time.
7. No analysis - no time for quality analysis. Purely data cruching and desktop research. Clients loves us because they outsource their work to us and we cannot say no.
advice_to_mgmt: Stuff turnover for around a year or often less tell you something!

headline: If the staff engagement strategy comprises fake reviews on social media, it speaks volumes of the workplace culture.
status:
6 January 2021
Helpful (6)
"If the staff engagement strategy comprises fake reviews on social media, it speaks volumes of the workplace culture."
1.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros:
AME is a well-trodden path from the technical world into financial services. Many have used it as a short stepping stone and done well. A larger number have slipped and died professionally whilst trying.

Depending on the role, some people get the opportunity to meet a lot of people in the industry. It’s a very steep learning curve and some of the on-the-job training for juniors is excellent, albeit self directed.

The company is always hiring. It’s not growing, you’re just being interviewed to replace the last person who was pushed out or got fed up and resigned.
cons:
There’s a reason it’s only a stepping stone. It’s a hell hole of a place to work. About 50% of staff don’t make it through the first twelve months either failing probation or being made ‘redundant’. You should only ever accept a position with AME if you are not working and consider it a short term stint whilst you look for something else.

They pay is lousy for what is expected and the work hours are long. Contractual hours are 830am to 6pm with an hour for lunch, or 42.5 hours per week. However leaving at 6pm is frowned upon. One well-known but unwritten KPI is the time you leave. In reality, junior staff should expect to work a 45-50 hour week, and more senior staff 50-55 hours per week. Every week. A call with a client in London can mean you won’t get out of the office until 9pm. There’s no time in lieu, it’s back to the office at 830 the next morning. AME is particularly difficult for people with family commitments.

The horrendous staff turnover saps efficiency and contributes to the longer hours. Efficiency and quality is reduced by forever training new people to do the same thing. For those staff that do manage to hold on to their job, the job satisfaction is low as you can never break free of the tedium. It’s also demoralising watching your friends and colleagues be bullied and sacked one after the other.

The most vile part of AME is the toxic, back-stabbing culture that stems from the owner. He cannot relate to people and has big problems with trust. He can’t be trusted and he trusts no-one. It’s a vicious cycle. He’s convinced that every member of staff is inherently lazy and will do nothing given the opportunity. Every control system (e.g. internal office CCTV, email monitoring, keystroke logging, work hour recording) plays into this his obsession that staff are stealing (time). All decisions and expenses however small go across his desk.

At the same time, staff don’t trust management, and rightfully so given the frequent lies and u-turns. There is no honesty between staff and management. Anyone who objects to the company direction-du-jour will just end up being the next person in line to be bullied until they resign or be ‘retrenched’. Being too committed to one direction might find you favour temporarily, but once the wind changes you’re exposed.

Management is utterly ineffective and concentrated with the owner. Formal management structures have been dissolved and change on a whim. All are designed to play staff off against one another and feed information on supposed individual staff underperformance back to the owner.
advice_to_mgmt: If you don’t want Glass Door sit at the top of the Google results when someone searches for AME, stop placing fake reviews. The more often a page is updated, the higher in the search results it is placed by the search engine algorithms. The bland and unrealistic positive reviews invite more comments from staff who would otherwise be silent.

pros: Career Progression to a psychiatric ward, as a patient

headline: Nothing changes
pros: Racked my brains, can’t think of a single positive
cons:
I worked at AME a few years ago, so to see the current crop of (very) negative reviews is simultaneously unsurprising and remarkable. Remarkable because it seems as though nothing has changed in all these years. 

Still sounds like Shaun Browne is bullying and mistreating people.

The atmosphere still sounds toxic.

The culture of the organization is still riven with problems caused by Shaun.

The quality of the work still sounds like it is very materially compromised by the extraordinarily high staff turnover, the lack of development and a leadership team that have absolutely no idea about the mining industry. 

Indeed I was often put in a position of either having to lie to clients about what work had been done, or having to profusely apologize for the substandard quality of the work, all while “the leadership” actually hid (and I mean actually physically hid). 

My time at AME was an eye opening experience, to see how an organisation should not be run and to work for someone I believe to be a genuinely unpleasant individual. 

I would caution anyone thinking about accepting a job here to reconsider and also recommend that organisations considering engaging AME for work to think about the quality of output they require.

headline: Exciting place to work
status:

"Exciting place to work"
5.0
★★★★★
Current Employee
pros:
AME has shifted from its old model into a fast paced, technically advanced and energetic start up. The work culture is collaborative and team based, and the staff are highly capable and technically skilled. If you enjoy being challenged and engaging in high-level thinking, then you will relish working at AME. 

Also, just for the other readers out there, take no note of the particularity nasty reviews as they are merely the the bitter resentments of a couple of former staff members who are each leaving multiple reviews in order to try to discredit the company. They clearly have a lot of time on their hands. I feel sorry for them.
cons: Because of the fast paced environment, the scheduling and task specification was sometimes disorganised and confusing but management is currently taking steps to rectify this issue.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you're doing

headline: This is the one review to rule them all
status:
8 August 2017
Helpful (55)
"This is the one review to rule them all"
1.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros: I got to write the cons on Glassdoor when I left. These reviews are smuggled into the office like western media into North Korea. These reviews give the poor souls still trapped there hope for the future. Plus they are also good for a laugh on Friday when you get beer. Oh look. A single. Realistic. Pro.
cons:
This website has said a great deal about AME. I don’t see any point in repeating what has already been said by past employees. It clearly doesn’t stop people from entering through the door for an interview. Therefore, the aim of this review is to stop people from even bothering to apply for anything posted by this company.

The worst thing about this company is not the physically demanding hours and pathetic excuse for a wage (although these two reasons are pretty bad). No, the worst thing about this company is how it will change you psychologically. It will warp you. It will corrupt you. The perverse nature of simply existing within these walls will destroy you. And the worst part is you won’t even notice it. Not until you tell friends. You’ll even joke about. You’ll say something like…

“Someone else got fired today. It’s the third one this month. And they’ve only been here for two days! Then gone, poof. I didn’t even bother remembering their name. I don’t bother remembering anyone’s name unless they’ve been here for over a month”. Then you’ll probably laugh. HAHAHAHAHA.

Your friends will be shocked. They’ll probably say something like. “I can’t believe such a terrible place exists. You have to leave”. And you’ll just shrug it off. Maybe you’ll blame the terrible job market. Or maybe you'll point out the fact that rent doesn’t pay itself. However, it doesn’t change the fact you laughed.

Think about it. You laughed, you mocked someone in the exact same situation as you. They also exist in a terrible job market and I bet they have to pay rent too. You saw someone in the same terrible situation as you and you joked and laughed at their misery. 

Aren’t you also miserable? Of course you are. You work at AME. Why are you laughing at someone in the exact same situation as you? Would you laugh a homeless person on the street? Or someone lying on a hospital bed? I know the laughter is ironic. It is the cynical snickering that comes from black humour. Everyone here shares the same fate. United in adversity, as you will read in all the other reviews. But ask yourself. Right now. As someone who has not been tainted by AME. Would you laugh if someone else got fired for doing nothing wrong in their first few days? If you’re already at AME, it is too late. But hey, at least there’s beer on Friday right? 

And this is why AME is so terrible. It is so cancerous that it strips you of basic human compassion. If you work here you will no longer be able to look at people as if they were actually people. New people are just sacrifices, a fresh batch of souls cooking in the oven for the CEO. Working here will remove something that is basically ingrained into you at birth because you cannot believe something so perversely inhumane (the CEO) has the audacity to assume the form of a normal functioning human being.

Beware the wolf in sheep’s clothing. If he’s charming to you in the interview (if you even get what could pass off as an interview), press the Glassdoor button. He will be so flustered you’ll think English is his second language. He might even get out some paper and draw a lot of diagrams to prove god knows what.
advice_to_mgmt:
How to Make a Painkiller (Cocktail)

2 oz Pusser's rum
4 oz Pineapple juice
1 oz Orange juice
1 oz Cream of coconut
Grated Nutmeg
Pineapple Wedge

1. Add all of the ingredients into a shaker and fill with ice.
2. Shake vigorously and strain into a hurricane glass or snifter filled with crushed ice.
3. Garnish with freshly grated nutmeg and a pineapple wedge.

Reading this recipe was a complete waste of your time and an excellent showcase of what it feels like working at this company. However, if you ignore my many warnings and accept an offer here, please use this recipe to deal with the crippling physical and psychological damage you will receive.

headline: Disgusting place to work. Avoid.
status:
21 July 2017
Helpful (33)
"Disgusting place to work. Avoid."
1.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros: Your colleagues are generally decent and united in the shared disrespect of Shaun Brown.
cons:
The problems with AME lie directly with the owner, Shaun Browne. At best, his management is comically awful with compulsive decision making, value-destroying about-turns and a child-like understanding of the technical aspects of the mining and oil and gas industries. At worst, Shaun Browne is a chronic bully - mentally, verbally and physical. He appears to contrive tension by pitting staff against each other. Senseless personnel changes are ongoing and poorly communicated. You could suddenly be reporting to someone else or, unbeknownst to you, people reporting to you could suddenly be reporting to a different colleague. 
Shaun Browne has a Trump-like ego and is blithely unaware of his own ineptitude. He has owned this business for over 25 years and literally knows nothing else outside those four walls. It is painfully obvious to even the youngest of analysts who have worked in professionally-run organisations that he is quite clueless. Unfortunately this makes Shaun Browne quite condescending and will constantly remind the staff that he has "being doing this longer than anyone else" and considers that justification for his poor decision making.
If you’re going for a BD role, do not expect to last for longer than 6 months. Otherwise, if you show any initiative you will be exploited mercilessly and dumped after a couple of years. The office is made up with those trying to work out what is going and those that are trying to leave. Do not fall for his faux charm and self-deprecation - it is fake as the positive reviews he organises for this site.
advice_to_mgmt: It is painfully obvious, to both employees and clients, how bad a job you're doing. Stop kidding yourself about getting PE on board and wind it up.

headline: Glassdoor for Sale
status:
7 July 2017
Helpful (38)
"Glassdoor for Sale"
1.0
★★★★★
Current Employee
pros: Everyday is one day closer to death! If you can last more than a year at AME, that is worth putting on your Resume.
cons:
DO NOT BELIEVE ANY POSITIVE POSTS ABOUT AME!!

The only thing worse than working at AME is knowing that AME can pay third party companies, or even Glassdoor itself to remove some of the negative posts and place higher weighting to positive comments, that have been clearly written by the owner or his immediate family. I have previously been tasked with signing up to 'Internet Reputation' companies that we pay to try to improve our image on Glassdoor.

If you are applying for a Business Development or Human Resources position, don't bother! I my 2 years here I have not seen anyone last more than 4 months, most last only a week or so.

Turnover here is huge, circa 60-70% per year. The people that stay (myself included) are either brainwashed, have limited opportunities elsewhere due to the market, or are just starting out and need to prove themselves.

There are no perks, the owner of the company tries to be charming but once you're there he will dictate every aspect of your employment down to the colour short you wear, where you will sit (which changes weekly), and he even tries to interfere with people's personal lives. To say the owner is a micromanager is the understatement of the year.

Nightmares will become commonplace. Long hours are expected. You will be given 10 times the amount of work that would normally be expected. Your job title will change monthly and if you are good at your job, he will pile more and more work on that person until they break. It is heartbreaking to see because these are some of the best people I have ever worked with. Without the owners constant interfering and crazy behaviour, this company could go places. Unfortunately the company remains stagnant, always trying to replace lost staff, instead of focussing on what it's good at.

Please do not accept a job here unless you have absolutely no choice. But if you do, to sum up a post put up here about a year ago, you will find we are 'together in adversity!'

Contact current or ex-staff to confirm all this.
advice_to_mgmt: Remove the owner from the day to day operations of this company and maybe there would be a chance for this company to succeed and for the culture to improve. But even his trusty sidekick is no better. If for 25 years you haven't found out what the problem is, then maybe it's you!

headline: CEO is a second rate con man

The single biggest issue that I (and everyone else) has with AME is the CEO. He initially comes across as charming and dare I say it.. friendly. It's a very thin veneer, as soon as you're onboard he shows himself to be the slimy, arrogant and downright abusive snake that he is. If you don't sink into the background, you will get fired. Please, do yourself a favour and avoid AME, you are better than this company.
advice_to_mgmt: Be upfront and honest about what you want, learn about modern business practices, outsource to a decent marketing company, stop deluding yourself with this nonsense about being two years behind Google, having better programming than Microsoft etc. In reality you're not even close to the standard we've seen from your competitors and are unlikely to ever really be competition to them.

headline: Great People in a Fast Moving Space
status:
3 March 2017
Helpful (4)
"Great People in a Fast Moving Space"
4.0
★★★★★
Current Employee
pros:
I have been working at AME London for a couple of years and enjoy the fast pace and changing environment, as well as the forward looking nature of management who are always setting challenging but innovative goals! 
Excellent travel opportunities and ability to gain more responsibility extremely fast if you want it. You get to work with a tight team of intelligent people who are experts in their sector and enjoy what they do. 
You also get to interact with a huge range of clients and have a real input into a machine that sets tight targets to grow completely new and independent tools based on the newest computing technology.
cons: Working tightly and communicating with global offices can be difficult, but this is manageable. You can travel significantly, but you do have scope to mitigate this.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep the innovation & product development moving forward on the path its going, Continue to set the trend on the technology and AI side of research.

headline: The bottom rung
pros:
- The middle and lower levels of management (industry directors and your immediate manager and advisors) will explain your work with you clearly and help you learn whatever systems you may need to master to do your job to the best of your ability
- Camaraderie is strong in the face of adversity
- If you have a tough skin and know how to lick managerial boots, you will likely succeed here
- When the boss is overseas, the environment improves immensely and you may do your job well
- If you're starting out on the path of your career, this is a good stepping stone—so long as you only stay here as long as is respectable with regards to your resume
- Some positions allow you to clock off at your contracted time and leave your work at work (although, most expect overtime on an almost daily basis)
- If you do your job well and help others wherever possible, you will likely make firm friends through respect and trust
cons:
- The boss doesn't know where the company is going (or if he does know where he wants it to go, he can't make up his mind how to get there, so be prepared to work your fingers off on a whim of his, to then have all that work disregarded the next week, to then be forced to focus on something else)
- You will get intimidated by the boss on a daily basis, whether he's in the office or overseas
- High turnover rate of staff, due to dissatisfaction with the work environment, intimidation, stress and lack of respect shown by upper management, which means you will likely have to make friends quickly, and see them leave soon after
- Quantity is valued over quality, so don't expect to do your best work here
- Staff members are overworked and not remunerated for extra efforts or overtime
- Culture of backstabbing and mistrust is rampant
- Family-run business, so the boss thinks he's a king and you are his servants
- Do not expect your suggestions to be taken seriously—you are there to carry out orders, no matter how illogical they may be
- The boss will charm you into thinking he values your opinions, but he doesn't, he simply wants to deceive you about his true character—but you will learn in time and through experience
- If you are considering work experience here as part of a degree, be prepared for a hard slog—you will be treated terribly, the system will not be explained to you in full and you will likely walk away from the experience with a warped view of the industry
- Do not take a job here unless you have no other choice

Any rating over two stars for this company and its boss are likely written by management. Do not trust any reviews that claim the environment is stimulating and creative or that you have opportunities to grow in this company. You do not, unless you have the same manipulative personality as its owner. Work outside of your contract will be thrust upon you but you will not thrive or be rewarded for extra duties.

This is not a 'disgruntled' ex-worker's review. This is an honest review, with a mind to warn anyone who may be considering a position here. Weigh up your options very carefully.
advice_to_mgmt:
- Management would do well to respect those who have come to work for them and to not treat them like 'things' that they own.
- Planning could be greatly improved upon to reduce time wasted on whimsical projects.
- Environment could be greatly improved upon by encouraging friendly interaction between all rungs of the business, perhaps through social events or worker perks.

headline: Circus is an understatement
pros:
It pays bills. Not very well, but pays them.
Only take a job here if desperate
The culture among staff has improved in the past year. Less backstabbing. Togetherness in adversity.
cons:
This workplace is a disgrace. Every negative review is true. The positive reviews are written by the Executive Chairman, Shaun Browne.
Long hours.
Run as a dictatorship by the Executive Chairman Shaun Browne.
Shaun Browne is a sociopath. AME is his play thing.
No consistent direction. Whole company changes course on the whims of Shaun Browne, which change weekly.
Staff treated as completely disposable. Turn over is very high.
No career advancement unless you are willing to play Shaun Browne's games. Without question.

headline: A Circus
pros: Nothing at all. A disgusting workplace. Maybe could be considered as not even a workplace, just a facade containing smoke and mirrors. There are a few 'incrowd' that suck knowledge from former industry workers then fire them within months. The owner only has this company as a 'play thing' to make himself feel good and make out he is big man full of mining/commodity knowledge. His real business is in real estate.
cons:
No real direction or review of your work. What you do can be checked by people that know less than you and can be OK with one and red inked by another. Backs to the wall. What a circus. 
Never ever saw a client in months with any AME employee. Maybe they don't exist. This would not surprise me with the company possibly only in existence as some type of tax dodge to cover the real estate dealings.
advice_to_mgmt: Grow up and be human. The people you hire need to feel they are valued, not just pieces of .... that you use and abuse.

headline: Fast-paced and competitive
pros:
AME has a highly competitive outfit; with lean business units in all cities it has office. It is flexible and fast-paced, constantly re-structuring and modernizing. 
Executive management sets the strategy (milestones and targets) to each research manager. These carry precise expectations regarding schedule and budget. At the same time there is great autonomy on how to conduct the research.
Typically research teams will have young engineers supporting senior consultants with lots of field experience. So work provides many opportunities to meet experts in the field, but is also lively and full of young ambitious people. Friday beers are almost like a religion.
Working hours are normal. But the environment extremely fast-paced and targets are always set to challenge the team. Improving productivity, quality and developing new products dominate management agenda since I joined. Ruthless pursuit for improvement that can be contagious, especially because management is fast in identifying and promoting good workers/ideas. But if you are not a competitive self-motivated person, this might not be the place for you. I have seen plenty of turnovers related to this mentality.
If you are highly driven, the learning curves are astonishing. Even though each team deals with training in their own way, engineering and economic experience abound. There is always an area of expertise new employees don’t have experience with, be it the economic valuation / marketing strategy, or the technical engineering side of natural resource projects.
cons:
AME is a family-owned business, this means decision making is fast and responsive but also very concentrated on the Executive Director. 
Part of IT is outsourced which is not ideal. 
For field engineers going into research, pay is not ideal.
They have coffee but it is terrible, bring your own.
advice_to_mgmt: Improved transparency on individual business units financial results. Making staff minority partners could improve pay, motivation and retention.

headline: Manager
pros: People join and leave very quickly. High staff turnover rate
cons: IT software is outsourcing which is not very professional in software production.
advice_to_mgmt: Thanks for your feedback. Our innovative, technical and extensive databases and software tools require both a large in-house software team and an outsourced team for additional help as we always want to ensure our staff have a great work-life balance and the work load is spread efficiently, effectively and fairly. We wish you all the best for the future.

headline: Bully and a Fraud - DON'T Do it!
pros: We got to drink a solitary beer at 6pm on a Friday....that's the only pro.
cons:

Management (1 person) is a bully and a liar. Regularly demeaned and bullied other staff members. 

Staff turnover is absurd - was the most senior member/longest serving member of staff having been there for 18 months. 

Encouraged to be economical with the truth with clients - never allowed to answer our own phones (!) and were not permitted to tell clients how many employees there were...

Absolutely no mining/technical knowledge from senior management - all smoke and mirrors. Left many clients intensely dissatisfied if not downright angry with the service.

headline: Low salary, little mobility
status:

Helpful (1)
"Low salary, little mobility"
1.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros:
Very cheap lunch and dinner provided by the company.
Not a lot of workload, and rather stable environment for retirement.
cons:
A lot of politics and redundant employees. Since chinese companies never lay off employees, some unproductive and low-skilled people get to stay and even be promoted. Probably because some people are getting too free, they start playing politics and gossips.

Strong hierarchy is everywhere, though colleagues come from MNC or with overseas academic background are generally more genial. Discrimination towards contract staff by perm staff exists.

Would not recommend to fresh graduates especially if you have good English skills/ energetic mindset.

headline: A big disaster! The worst company that I have worked for.
status:
27 July 2019
Helpful (2)
"A big disaster! The worst company that I have worked for."
1.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros: nothing can tell, except a big and famous bank.
cons: Unfriendly managers/senior. You are only a tool for them to achieve their goals. No training for new joiners and they suppose you can perform as an experienced staff. Top down, micromanagement, finger-pointing and always unnesscarry reporting, which seriously ruin the working environment. As a Chinese bank, it is quite conservative. You could not give them some advise and have diffrent opinions, or you may be considered as not following instructions. You must follow their own ways to do things. Office politics. High turnover rate. No project software makes things complicated. Poor benefits and no career path for contract staff.
advice_to_mgmt: If have better choices and want to grow, don't choose this bank, especially for younger generations.

headline: CH11, Acquisition, Cleaned house, hiring us college grads as scabs, gotta job!
status:
3 December 2012
"CH11, Acquisition, Cleaned house, hiring us college grads as scabs, gotta job!"
1.0
★★★★★
Current Employee
pros: the work is neither hard nor demanding and the new blood that coming on seems to be wanting to show their feathers and capabilities to the top brass who are still trying to figure out the direction given the entire change of the top levels
cons: the work isn't fulfilling and the change in leadership is seemingly lost in translation, not from Chinese to English, but from Silicon Valley-ish to Indianapolis/Atlanta lingo. The mash-up of Vista fame is not happening fast enough to make us famous in a good way.
advice_to_mgmt: get your tools and people to play well together in the same sandbox and we might have a chance to overcome the bad press of lawsuits, legal issues, financial troubles and the wounds caused to all the former employees who went through this stuff... it still effects the new people, even with a name change and new location (which is worse than the old location!)

Friendly colleagues
cons:
bonus never paid out on time and some quarters are miscalculated and skipped. 
salary hikes never paid on time and not upto the mark, 
every year restructuring and management in India doesn't have teeth, 
bad company for freshers (as you should not relax in your initial years),

Promotions/(very few) onsite opportunities happen NOT on the basis of calibre but years of experience in the organization, 
people who are close to managers and more years into the organisation always have the silver spoon.

Location

headline: Good if one is not ambitious. Works like a pyramid scheme, those who joined the company earlier call the shots.

low salary.
hikes are always delayed.
bangalore team not treated well by western counter parts.
advice_to_mgmt: Speak up for your employees, show professionalism by paying hikes on time, have a clear strategy and focus on one product instead of acquiring many companies and losing direction.

headline: Communists!!!!!!!!!!
pros: Knowledgeable colleagues, flexible timing and casual environment. If you have thirst to learn then this is the place but not through work but by personal interest only.
cons:
Hikes are always delayed, this is the only software company i know which gives arrears as they never give hikes on time. 
They say its intrapenuerial culture but profits are never shared with the employees. 
Only product company which is currently filling up freshers unlimitedly, and freshers are considered back ups for a 4-6 years experienced folks. 
Management in bangalore has lost focus on making this a world class RD centre, instead they are taking it to the level of a service company.
Technical direction of the company is to visit all the latest technologies but to invest in none, they just look for free softwares and trainings.
advice_to_mgmt:
Communicate with your employees especially about hikes, dont play delay tactics. 
You cannot make a good RD centre with freshers so start respecting your key members

headline: Casual but at times hierarchic

cons:

Not much transaparency from management
advice_to_mgmt:
poor salary structure:no proper hikes or bonus

headline: not recommended to join
pros: good to get direct customer services experience
cons: bad management, leading & communication
advice_to_mgmt: truly listen to employees, NOT ONLY from managers

headline: Company was run like it was owned by slumlords.
pros:
Great Product
Great People
Great Team Spirit
cons:
No Marketing
Highly political 
Management was completely out of touch
Lack of willingness to spend money on expansion
Felt like they were collecting maintenance in order to fun other "projects"
advice_to_mgmt: Sell the company to someone who will take advantage of it and doesn't use it as a money laundering scheme.

headline: Is has been satisfying.
pros: As a software consultant, my position is very flexibility and I have a lot of autonomy. I work with a supportive and collaborative team.
cons: The company and management does a poor job at communicating organization changes. The company doesn't do much in the way of community involvement or volunteering.

headline: Good place to work.
pros: Working with great talented people
cons: Poor top down communications at times.

headline: Started well but has gone downhill fast ever since.
pros:
When employees request time off it is usually granted. 
Co-workers are great to work with and good team atmosphere. Also has free coffee.
cons:
Upper management has no direction or vision. Workloads assigned to employees are totally unrealistic and the expectation is a workday of 10hours minimum. 
No communication from managers on job performance until you are blamed for not getting something done with the unreal workload.
Bonuses have not been paid starting the beginning of 2010 and no answer at all as to why or if they will be given.
advice_to_mgmt: Communicate. Figure out a direction and stick with it. Hire more staff to take some of the load off or you will continue to lose good employees.

headline: So so
pros: Work life balance is good.
cons:
No role model to follow in terms of technical talent.
Not good salary.
People with no real skills get recognized just because they can talk n talk.
No work from home.
No timely salary hikes.
advice_to_mgmt:
Management should lead by examples. People just quickly want to be managers so that they can just delegate the work. Once they are in that position, they start expecting employees under them to be innovator whereas in their time they were themselves less than ordinary.

Sales of products need to be improved. Just by cutting the cost no company can survive for long.

headline: OK place to work
pros:
Flexible work schedule
Nice colleages to work with
cons:
no advancement opportunities, you feel like a labor worker with too much to do everyday but no promotion regardless how much you've done
no training program in place
advice_to_mgmt: no clear vision as to what we are heading to as company in a whole, feels like whatever makes money, we will do it. No long-term plan to make our flagship product ERP better.

headline: Good potential if top management were replaced
pros: Good products but need development money
cons:
Senior management is very weak.
Development funding is skinny as company is in maintenance mode
Marketing is skinny and poor
advice_to_mgmt: Survey employees not filtered CEO input only

headline: Highly political environment
pros: Good industry to work in. CDC Software has a reasonably strong balance sheet, which is not always the case for technology companies, so that part of job risk is reduced.
cons: Promotions are often given to those with political skills while those with true ability are often passed over. Not an environment to work in if you think ability and hard work should trump politics.
advice_to_mgmt: Focus on creating true vision and value rather than on acquiring mediocre companies to offset falling revene in key product lines.

headline: CDC If not Great a Good Place to work
pros:
Very Flexible work timings.
Transparency.
Friendly Work Environment.
Strong Technical products, so you get to learn a lot.
Product base company so moderations and hikes are more or less same for all employees.
cons:
No Proper care given to the new employees.
Its the hard way to learn followed here.
advice_to_mgmt: Give more focus on the new resources.

headline: The place where software goes to die
pros: Gives life to software long past it's time.
cons: Kindergarten would best describe the work culture. Many good people who only speak when spoken to and answer very carefully. If your credo is to wake up everyday making a difference and doing the right thing you'll be sorely disappointed. If you are in sales, the clawback clauses on commissions will take your breath away. If you think you've earned a commission amount beware, it's just an advance that can be taken back at the whim of management.
advice_to_mgmt: Do the right thing.

headline: poor flow of knowledge and communication, poor time and resources management, outdated hardware, software, etc.
pros: some employees in senior positions (senior developers, qa's, etc.) are very talented, and the juniors/freshers may learn a lot from them - if there is good knowledge transfer.
cons: very good case of one hand not knowing what the other hand is doing. agile development means everyone is working in their own lane, and dont stray to the next one, not even a peek. people in one team dont know what people in the other teams are doing. agile environment has aggravated this. no time for anything other than strict 8+ hour of work. very poor work-social life balance, and what's worse, management doesnt acknowledge this.
advice_to_mgmt: acknowledge that employees are overworked, give them latest software tools, update outdated hardware, let them implement latest industry-ratified practices, give some freedom to employees to experiment, innovate, etc.

headline: Not an inspiring company...and that's the most positive way I could say it.
pros:
- its a job...if you're desperate, unmotivated, lack confidence or lack talent stick around
- the only honorable thing that keeps good people here are your co-workers, especially if you've been brought into CDC as an acquisition
- compensation is decent but bonuses are unreliable (even if owed they may not be paid for 3 months)
cons:
- no culture - strictly an unorganized, heartless business mostly full of stressed out, burnt out, apathetic employees
- no reason to innovate or step up to a challenge
- if you'd like to respect an organization and its leadership you will be frustrated here
advice_to_mgmt: - will a true leader please stand up...the chaos is managed, or at least attemptedl but true leadership is scarce

headline: Not fun
pros: many good people trying very hard
cons: lack of clear strategy beyond cutting costs
advice_to_mgmt: clarify strategy, unify management behind a bigger vision

headline: Technical Project Manager
pros:
telecommuting available
schedule flexibility
Not micro-managed, trusted by management
great staff of technical consultants to work with
cons:
no job security - constant lay offs
headquarters being far away from home
management decisions were not always well thought out
advice_to_mgmt: should not let good people go

headline: Great place to work while you can (before you get laid off)
pros: flexible time schedule, great pay and good bonus plan, nice people to work with, telecommuting is an option
cons: many management changes and some inconsistencies with project management. Didn't think before they laid people off in terms of the gap that would have to be filled in their absence.
advice_to_mgmt: Think before you act

headline: Has Potential ...
pros: There is a lot of talent in the Professional Services organization which makes for a great group of consultants to work with. The pay is good, bonuses are nice when paid on time and for a home-office based consultant travel is less than 50%, which is great if you have a family. The CDC Software client base I've worked with have been world class companies which make the consulting experience challenging but fulfilling.
cons: Management is not very transparent, 2009 bonuses for Q2 and Q3 have been paid late with no explanation, and turn over seems to be high these days. No pay raises this year due to the "economic downturn". Performance is completely based on billable utilization hours (how many billable hours you can log each week) which in turn doesn't leave a lot of room for creativity and career development opportunities (training, education, etc). Benefits are pretty basic and standard no bells or whistles.
advice_to_mgmt: Recognize your talent in PS and reward with more promotions from within the organization. There is a lot of talent in the organization that will go somewhere else who will.

headline: senior software developer
pros: good place to be, at times you really need pull things up and there is always a space for you to chip in and lead. Work culture is really good. as in u often see smiling faces :) you are paid enough. u get qualified people to work with, and knowledg sharing is boon, any finding is shared accross
cons: they pay a bit less from what is expected. in my team the growth is a problem as in there are not many options or room for me to achieve professional growth that m expecting.
advice_to_mgmt: increase they pay as there is a huge contribution from this set of employee, else expect people a bye bye coz ther are many options. but there are people in this company who would love to stay as long as possible and see it growing.

headline: Company in decline
pros: Talented staff and challenging work
cons: Integration of multiple acquisitions has been handled poorly, company appears rudderless and a lot of turnover
advice_to_mgmt: The issue is at the top as senior management, chairman of the board and major shareholder are one in the same.

headline: This office won't be here for long
pros: No good reason to work in the Vancouver office. Looks like they're shutting it down soon and transferring it all to India.
cons:
Very, very unstable at the senior management level with turnover, etc. Unilateral or lack of decision making at very top stall all the work at the subsidiary level, regardless of very solid business cases.

Layoffs across the board in all offices in Jan 2008 and June 2008. The Vancouver office experienced heavy layoffs in R & D in June 2008 and now only a small skeleton staff exists. Will likely do transition of remaining operations in 3 to 6 months.
advice_to_mgmt: Peter Yip the CEO doesn't seem to have a consistent strategy. Decisions don't seem logical or consistent.

headline: Only few annotations.
pros: The BI team in the company is the best that I worked it.
cons: Fairness from senior leaderships other mine.
advice_to_mgmt: Transparency in the conversations.

headline: Great Company to work for

pros: Company truly cares about employees. They show that by flying you to the headquarters for training to inform you about their culture. Also a fabulous steak dinner on the last night to socialize with others.
cons: I don't have any cons about this company

headline: Needs better re-investment in the employees
pros: Good resources, training available for other positions, but not sure if it will lead to a promotion or not as I was not there long enough.
cons: Benefits are lack-luster. Would have like to have seen a re-investment in the employee, such as 401k matching. This was one of the reasons I left the company.

headline: Doesn’t value employees
status:
10 February 2020
Helpful (1)
"Doesn’t value employees"
2.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros: The pay was decent and the employees were great people.
cons: No opportunities for annual raises, and no bonuses. They take top producers and execs on an extravagant trip Mexico, neglecting to realize that helping those top producers is a team effort. The company brings in billions, yet refuses to reward the employees who show up every day to support its success.
advice_to_mgmt: If you want to retain and recruit top talent, consider rewarding your employees with a bonus, annual raise, or even just a 401k match. You can’t expect to keep up with other companies if you don’t value your people.

headline: Love my branch
pros: I've been here 7+ years, and have always had a great relationship with my boss. Richard is super flexible and has always pretty much let me do what I want/need as far as leaving to take care of my daughter when she was still at home. I recently had an offer from another employer for considerably higher base pay, and he matched it. Shows that he values me as an employee.
cons: I know that at the Corporate level, they allow people to work from home - wish this were an option for me at the Branch level. Would love to telecommute a couple days a week.
advice_to_mgmt: not really a lot of room for advancement at the branch level. would consider moving into Underwriting, but know that when layoffs come around, I'd be first out the door, and I wouldn't have the security that I do at my Branch.

headline: Great Company
pros: Great Company with great Executive Management team.
cons: No advancement opportunities and no annual reviews for raises.
advice_to_mgmt: Thank you for your review.

headline: Great work environment with work-life balance
pros: CCMC provides a great, family-like culture and encourages employees to have work-life balance. The company has a longstanding positive reputation in the community and it's wonderful to hear about CCMC's customer-focused mission to help home owners.
cons: It would really enhance the benefits if the company provided a 401k match and some form of paid family leave.

headline: Great Team. Great Culture.

pros:

• The VP of Marketing, David Arrnet is AMAZING! I always feel listened to and supported. He is also great at encouraging a work-life balance and really helps continue to grow and push our team to do the best we can.
cons:
• Communication between different departments is not always clear or even there which can make it difficult when working on bigger initiatives
• Benefits (mainly no matching on 401K) are not the best

Fantastic leadership that really listens to their employees and is not afraid to try new ideas. 
Culture is like a big family. 
Incredible opportunities for growth, increasing education and sharpening skills. 
Forward thinking and striving for cutting-edge technologies.
A good work/life balance is promoted.
cons: 401 K is not a match; however, we do have a home loan benefit that is fantastic.

headline: Branch Manager
pros: The newly launched, proprietary LOS system is by far the best in the industry. Management provides loan officers business development tools like Home Buyers Marketing, MBS, OSI and MBS Highway. We have an in-house coaching program through Rewire and an annual sales rally. Programs are constantly being added to provide loan officers opportunities to assist more buyers. Management is accessible and responsive.
cons: Some departments provide better service than others. Brand awareness outside of the Colorado market is less than desirable. No matched 401k.
advice_to_mgmt: Share your vision and plans for the future growth of the company. Where are we going and how are you going to get us there? Take the time to visit your branches. Survey employees, you might be surprised at the insights you are able to glean.

Former Employee
pros: There were a few decent folks.
cons: Worst company I ever worked for. Within a month of leaving, management handed my closed loan client base to someone and told them to solicit my clients. Mind you, these were self sourced clients and mgmt told me prior to starting there that they would never solicit my clients. They also have a horrendous underwriting dept. Closing a loan here was worth than walking through a swamp filled with alligators.

headline: Great company
pros: Managers did not micro manage and was a very relaxed, yet productive environment

pros: Everyone really cares about you and wants you to succeed. They have great technology and corporate is designed to make life easier for LO's.

advice_to_mgmt: Maybe figure out a way to drive some leads to LO's.

headline: Non-exempt position

cons: Male employees paid more for same positions than female employees. Nepotism present, standing up to alleged mistreatment frowned upon .
advice_to_mgmt: End the denial of potential corruption and nepotism, it will most likely ultimately harm your company's success.

headline: Does not pay equally for same work
status:
12 February 2018
"Does not pay equally for same work"
1.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros: The office space is nice.
cons:
Not all loan officers are paid equally. Different commission structure for different people, not based on experience, but based on who recruited you. New LOs with small production are paid a higher percentage than seasoned LOs who were hired on their own without a recruiter. 

Manager pays commissions late. I was paid 30 days past my contract date, more than once. (60 days past loan closing) You have to hound them to get paid.
advice_to_mgmt: Treat all LOs equally. Pay commissions on time.

If you indicate to management you want to grow your career they'll pat your back and send you back to your desk. This place is run terribly because the executive management team is a joke and the President is clueless so it's not likely to change anytime soon.
advice_to_mgmt: Get rid of most of your executive management team! They have no idea what they are doing anyways...

advice_to_mgmt: Enforce rules and policies consistently or not at all.

headline: Amazing Company to Work For
pros: This is a company that understands that taking care of your employees leads to happy customers. Their values and desire to do the most transparent and honest business made it a company I could get on board with. It is apparent why they have grown so large, as their commitment to hiring individuals of integrity and screening processes during hiring demonstrate. In an industry where anyone with a pulse can get hired with no regards to the consumers experience, Cherry Creek has really excelled at separating themselves from that stigma. I have never worked for a mortgage company that focuses so hard on helping employees have life balance, even to the extent of investing in career growth curriculum and life coaching for the employee. Most of the employees have been here for a long time with hopes of never leaving, and I can see why.
cons: I can't think of any.

headline: Non existent management
pros: Very kind people working there with good intentions

Internally he was made fun of as the No man because of ignorance he just said no to any loan that wasn't a cookie cutter loan not because he meant it but because he feared it biting him in the butt from lack of knowledge of the business and industry. Processing needs an attitude adjustment, everyone in the office is related or friends, it was almost like walking into a cult
advice_to_mgmt: Hire without fear to bring in experienced knowledge people and allow room for change with the time. When there is a problem with your staff that has been there for a long time, listen, maybe that's why your not growing

headline: Productive, sometimes stressful, rewarding.
status:

Current Employee
pros: Helping those looking for mortgages to better understand the process can be very rewarding. It's a real team environment where people work together to get the job done. The atmosphere is typically friendly, helpful and results driven.
cons: There much on the job training rather than formal training, especially for lower levels of management.
advice_to_mgmt: Focus on training new managers on policies and regulations in dealing with their team.

headline: Opportunity Knocks
pros: As an employee, I feel a tremendous amount of support from Cherry Creek Mortgage and its executive team. In my experience, there is a very open line of communication between myself and my boss, and he is very receptive to my ideas and provides me the support I need to move forward with the projects that I'm tasked to lead.
cons: The mortgage industry is very dynamic and requires you to be adaptable to change. CCMC's management team is very responsive to industry trends and regulatory pressures, so this means that, as an employee, you have to be flexible and willing to adjust at those times when the company's focus changes from one directive to another. I think that this same critique could be applied to any mortgage company that is looking to survive and thrive within the current industry environment.
advice_to_mgmt: We have branches spread across a large number of states. I'd love to see an initiative that supports and strengthens our "culture" across those branches, so that those in corporate have a better feel for what is happening at the branch level and vice versa.

headline: Hurry up and wait for mgmt
status:

pros: Cherry Creek is a friendly, laid back place to work, with flexible managers, and a dedicated staff of people at corporate who take their job seriously and work extremely hard to support loan originators in the field.
cons: It seems like the strategy for business development is changed on a weekly basis. Low follow through on initiatives by upper mgmt, and it seems like the corporate staff is caught in a cycle of scrambling to keep up. Low career mobility.
advice_to_mgmt: Set a goal, tell the company about it, know how your going to reach it, then do it! Enough of the "well lets see how this goes" mentality!

headline: OVP(DE), high starting salary point, low increasing rate
status:
24 October 2020
"OVP(DE), high starting salary point, low increasing rate"
2.0
★★★★★
Current Employee
pros:
- The colleagues in low and middle level are friendly
- The comradery level is huge
- The salary starting point is high and generous
cons:
- Salary increasing rate is horrendously low
- Personnel in the manger level are harsh and mean
- VP is caring expenses very much
- Lack of support and resources
- The office is low-tech while working on a project related to IT education in primary schools
- Terrible communication between middle level and management level
advice_to_mgmt:
- Salary incresing rate should be higher
- Be realistic, don't just stay in the ivory tower, look into the real job market
- Be more generous on the expenses and working hour
- Input more on high-tech equipment

headline: Good pay amidst questionable management
status:
20 April 2020
"Good pay amidst questionable management"
3.0
★★★★★
Current Employee
pros: The pay is good when compared to universities in other countries.
cons:
The management focused on traditional journal impact factors, thus developed indicators unfair to new and emerging disciplines. If you are working on an old discipline and published in IF >4 journals you will do well here. But if you aspires to establish yourself in a new area, and published conferences, books, and new journals, you will find little support here.

Also that the management seldom consults its faculties before deploying new policies. Most policies were discussed behind closed door and decreed university wide.
advice_to_mgmt: Promote good researchers from emerging disciplines into the core management team. Look at citation counts across all publications, not just journal IF, in measuring research rigor.

advice_to_mgmt: At least the management needs to increase the salaries of the staff according to the pay scale of the industrial level so as to maintain a good financial balance between the academics and industry.

headline: Limiting
pros:
- boss is good
- colleagues are friendly
- interesting work
- good restaurants
cons:
- no career advancement opportunities 
-no funding of junior research staff for conferences unlike other universities.
- don’t bother applying if you cannot get at least an Assistant Professorship in CityU. Anything below is a waste of time.
- lower salary than HKUST or HKU and even CUHK. 
- miserable annual leave allowance (1 day per month if you are contract staff)
- admin workload is dumped onto research staff. Best ever : they asked for ‘volunteers’ to get free manpower.
- no space. 
- expected to get own funding to publish papers but refuses to let junior staff be a PI - please go to point 1 again
advice_to_mgmt: Fix the cons.

headline: IT Analyst
pros:
1 "Predictable" environment (politics)
2 Industry match pay a bit close
3 Only 'yes' to director, can not provide alternate better solutions (because directors know better and need you say yes).
4 You have IT skill, you silly. You play good powr point, you promoted
5 You learn some skill from manager (mostly little thing here there)
6 Work many years do repeat jobs and also try predict what director think (so you can have crystal mind bowl).
cons:
1 Lots of incompetent managers focus on politics not deliver work
2 reeward not on meritocriacy but politic
3 Senor management for support apps never like promote you even you reliable and no mess up.
4 You try to provide advice better than vendor but management listen to vendor not your opinion. Your not matter.
advice_to_mgmt:
1 Many good managers left you because you can not appreciate good one
2 Do not concentrate on politics but deliver to user
3 Promote hard working people not based on you prefer like someone based on apearrance
4 Even you dislike promoting hard workng people, at least show appreciation. I worked many years before leaving and you never even know me all that time. I left but you never know

headline: Full of resource, full of procedures, full of waste-your-time party
pros:
You can have top grade pc, laptop
Equipment for works is not a problem
80% people leave office on time, OT is not a trend
Many many training optional for you, these are expensive if you finance on your own
Work load is fairly reasonable
Office environment is good
Company pays attention to work safety
Electricity subsidize
Gym room, shower room, holiday house
cons:
Bureaucratic management, lots of excessive redundancy in management structure
You have to attend enormous safety meetings which contribute nothing to safety
Politics require you act like you agree and support those un useful safety measurement, that would give you schizophrenia
Some team have to take up standby work in turn with no fair compensation. If no actual work during standby duty you will have no rest time given, and have to work next day.
advice_to_mgmt:
Standby duty promotes the most un safety issue.
Should allocate more manpower and resource to off-load regular staff standby duty work
Trim down excessively grown office procedure from time to time to combat company by-born bureaucracy
Open and fair measurement to safety procedure or meeting. Justify the existence
Give capacity to innovation, accept the cost of innovation and implicit risk of failure. Stop slogan work, support actual innovation.

headline: Extremely picky management
status:
31 May 2016
Helpful (7)
"Extremely picky management"
2.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros:
1. For non-operational-critical roles, you get to leave work at 5:30PM.
2. Compared to other local companies, they use the most advanced technologies in terms of hardware and software.
3. Everyday at 4PM, there is a stand-up-and-exerise break, when people get to relax and chat.
4. Pay is well on-time. (Consider a Pros, compared to some small local companies.)
cons:
1. Senior Leadership are extremely picky, even on small details like text fonts and formats.
2. Mid-level managers have a tendency to follow blindly without questioning authorities.
3. As part of IT, options (specially objection) from Business Users are mostly ignored.
4. Very old-fashioned contractor system, in which you might have an employment period as short as 2-months. Depending on budget / approval, rather than your performance.
advice_to_mgmt: Be open-minded and listen more to employees and users.

status:
11 January 2021
"Mixed bag with MSFT"
4.0
★★★★★
Current Employee

cons: GitHub culture of innovation and community contributions is fading as MSFT becomes dominant culture. Far too many white dudes and not nearly enough females. First place I've ever worked at that does not offer a referral bonus. Not a place I can fully utilize my experience or grow my career.

headline: Diversity is Lip Service, Amazing Peers just terrible Mgmt
pros: Friendly cohorts/peers and cool network of amazing people after you head out, good company events (when there isn't covid) and opportunities to travel, sign-on benefits are really nice.
cons: Leadership - from top to bottom. Actually listen to your ERG groups, they are the best part and the backbone of your company. Listen to your good managers and stop keeping the rotten ones.
advice_to_mgmt:
I was at Github a while back, several months ago. I wanted to give it a minute so I could write a level-headed review. Now I'm at a another company and chilled out and reflective about my experience. 

I'm going to start with my criticism of the ERG groups (Octogatos, Blacktocats, and Octoqeers) because I think it's both Github's biggest strength and downfall. They have great people there that they completely underutilize and continue to lose.

While I did see a lot of growth and opportunity during my years at the company, as well as women in positions of leadership -- overall Github's efforts for diversity and inclusion are largely lip service and anecdotal - as some of those same women in leadership unfortunately contribute to the problem all the same as the men. A layoff last year included mostly women (and more specifically BIPOC women) which was whispered through the company and handled TERRIBLY. I also saw several woman (incl women of color, as well as lgbt women incl myself) leave my own team within my short time there. As a matter of fact, my sr manager only hired former employees from the same regional company s/he had previously worked for. For this position, they had the opportunity to interview (frankly over)qualified men and women color for a sr engineering position which took quite literally over a dozen hours to interview for, only to have an engineer GIVEN to us from sr leadership...because somebody knew him from our Parent company -- I never even interviewed him for the position. What the hell was the point of 12 hours of interviews and lengthy greenhouse submissions, then?

Overall turnover and burnout rate continues to be an issue as people were hired and left shortly thereater, from what I could see, an average of a year. Nepotism in management runs very deep. Escalations to leadership are unheard and empty, as on more than one occasion Ive heard of employees (incl myself) being written up for speaking out for feeling uncomfortable. If you want to know about the company's history of performative bullcrap, look no further than when they signed a contract with ICE only to have a wave of internal employee complaints including a TOWN HALL where the head of legal spoke out against our CEO. This also spread on twitter, news media outlets, and the internal employee petition that was signed by many people (myself included) which you can still find as a pull request if you're working there. Services like the Octogatos and Blacktocats are great and a wonderful start to reel people in but ultimately the buck stops at senior leadership who seem to believe in employee empowerment & open door policies at a surface level only. This does not diminish the work of the wonderful people overseeing and contributing to these employee initiatives and is indicative only of the program management that stifles their efforts. This goes from individual team leadership all the way up to HR and the executive board. 

This is all contrary to the supposed work-life balance and unlimited PTO the remote infrastructure would indicate. Much like other elite tech companies, Github suffers the Silicon Valley-esque allure wherein they'll convince you that you're a chosen Golden Child for being blessed for the opportunity to be working for them. Imposter Syndrome is talked about often, even for new hires, but then when you actually do your 1:1s or skip level and want to give open door policy feedback about/to your manager - you can quite literally retaliated against. That isn't to say that Github doesn't have wonderful managers among the lot, just that they are trapped in an unfortunately nepotistic system that is def present from the top, down. After spending a few years there I'm actually more convinced that these lectures about Imposter Syndrome during new hire orientation were actually meant to beat you down/convince you that you shouldn't work there, so that you feel bad for speaking up. "We all feel it! Don't worry! Just talk to your manager if you're having problems with xyz because we'll be here for you." It's baloney. In my own direct experience (as well as others, the network of people who have left the company is large and we do talk), that...is definitely the case. 

The benefits package is nice but leaves a lot to be desired when work hours aren't respected. Maternity leave for mothers is great until mothers are still pressured or feel bothered by upper management to do daily check ins. "COVID flex time" as I'll call it based on the company memo that was sent out, is given as lip service but when someone in your family is effected by the pandemic - suicide, healthcare workers, general anhedonia and new severe depression diagnosis are a few I heard -- there is virtually no sympathy given and project deadlines are all that matter. The best parts all come when you onboard, which is nice. The telecommunications stipend, home office setup, and offer to buy back the laptop were all nice. 

Lack of clarity and constant restructuring of departments are par the course and expected. If you're a new hire now, I would quite literally expect that you have a new manager and quite possibly new team by the end of the year due to high turnover. This is every team, though I saw it especially often on cloud services, security, and legal. 

Overall it seems like my experience at Github is pretty typical. You'll find some really awesome peers, coworkers, and management really trying to do the right thing. But overall everyone gets fed up with the entrenched nepotism and lack of oversight (as well as frequent unheard employee complaints) eventually. *shrugs*

headline: Resting on reputation at this point
status:
5 November 2020
Helpful (17)
"Resting on reputation at this point"
3.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros:
• Life changing pay + benefits + stipends
• Remote first organization, home office setup
• Extremely talented ICs - some of the smartest people I've worked with
• Passionate legacy employees
• World class products & experiences
• Opportunity to learn and grow
• MSFT acquisition added much more resources
cons:
GitHub is no longer the friendly, employee first driven company it had built it's reputation on. Since the MSFT acquisition, the environment has changed drastically, leaving behind very few remnants of once a thriving culture. 

• Cliquey. Very personality driven culture; character is less important. 
• Not a lot of empathy. Demanding hours & workloads increase by the day. 
• Constant change without much transparency. Lots of re-orgs. 

• Review process is broken with no ability to respond to critique.
• Fail-fast, fail-small mentality, with little margin for error

• Does not value diversity! 
• GitHub actively has an open ICE contract. 
• Women and POC have an incredibly high turn over rate and are paid significantly less than their white colleagues.
• There is only 9% diversity in leadership.
• ERGs do a majority of the labor to push diverse agendas and equity.
advice_to_mgmt: Stop promoting this company as one with "values". Hire leadership and managers who have empathy and care about the company, not those looking to jump on an MSFT rocketship. Have accountability for decision making that affects whole teams and work streams.

headline: Some days were great. Others sucked away your soul.
status:
21 August 2019
Helpful (33)
"Some days were great. Others sucked away your soul."
3.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros:
-Benefits are good. 
-Remote work can be good. 
-Company is strong. 
-Microsoft helping GitHub to mature. 
-Microsoft channel is huge for enterprise sales.
cons:
- Clicks. Build the right relationships or your career will be limited. While this is true everywhere I've worked, it was more noticeable in certain pockets. 
- Poor management in some areas. CMO is desperately needed.
- Rotating door in some departments. When everyone is underperforming, maybe it's time to replace the leadership. 
- Claim to support fail-fast, fail-small mentality, but will punish people for it at reviews. 
- Their 360 review process is implemented poorly. I've seen several people be hurt by feedback that the subject never received nor could respond to. 
- Remote work success depends on management. New CEO is in the office and rewards "tap on the shoulder" availability. 
- They are trying to shift to being decision-oriented, but in practice, decisions are made much higher in the organization than they should.
advice_to_mgmt:
- Practice what you preach about making decisions. 
- Give people the benefit of the doubt and an opportunity to try, fail, and learn.
- Be careful about rewarding proximity in a remote-oriented environment.

headline: Amazing benefits, respectful and inclusive culture. Overall a great place to work.
status:
25 September 2018
Helpful (17)
"Amazing benefits, respectful and inclusive culture. Overall a great place to work."
5.0
★★★★★
Current Employee
pros: The ability to work remotely, unlimited vacation, good pay, excellent healthcare benefits, 401K matching, learning and development stipend. I work in a fantastic team with kind, hard-working and easy-going people. Since I am a remote employee, I log in every day thinking about how lucky I am to have joined such a great company where people treat me with respect and where I do not have to commute. Sure, there are times when there's confusion, not clear direction and ambiguity, or other times when the company has sold their product to companies or to government agencies that seem to oppose company values, but this happens in all companies. In spite of those things, which I consider a few bumps in the road, I find that the company has an amazing culture and that they spend a lot of effort in trying to keep the culture open, friendly, respectful and inclusive. Sure, things have changed, and maybe 2 years ago, the culture was better than now, but even so, this is much better than so many other companies that have strict hierarchies, bully and toxic cutures, or that give you barely 10 days of time off. I feel happy and valued at GitHub and it has improved my quality of life ten-fold from my previous job. I feel that many people at GitHub do not realize how good it is at GitHub and they focus on the few negative areas that can be improved, and do not realize that other companies are so much worse. My personal experience has been great and all in all it's one of the best companies to work for, and I have already been lucky to work for 2 other amazing companies.
cons: I am very concerned that this is too good to stay this way, and my biggest concern is about the GitHub acquisition. Other cons are that there is ambiguity and constant change. Also, lately we have more restrictions about much we can spend on the phones we use for work or laptops get now replaced less often. This makes me feel that will be even tighter once we are under Microsoft.
advice_to_mgmt: Improve communication. Sometimes, several months go by before we have a company all-hands meeting. Concerned about the company being acquired by Microsoft.

headline: Chaos and Incompetence Abound
status:
11 July 2018
Helpful (60)
"Chaos and Incompetence Abound"
2.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros:
The benefits are outstanding the the pay is decent. There is a full bar at HQ if you are really into drinking.

You don't have to use your real name. Everyone uses monikers like the 1995 movie, Hackers. You can even change your title to "Nasty Woman" before an election and that's HR approved.
cons:
The management lackluster and direction is constantly changing. Re-orgs occur quarterly due to the lack of experience and direction of leadership. At this point it's just rearranging the deck chairs of the Titanic. Anyone who has worked for a grown-up company will not be able to stand the immaturity.

The positive reviews here don't surprise me. The majority of the company is young and lacks any experience. So to those people, a full bar and free lunch is a dream job. But the real story is one of paying lip service to volunteering and diversity. Organizing large volunteer efforts only to put in 30 minutes before leaving to go and spend several thousand dollars on a five star restaurant. But it's all okay because we selected a city to visit that is "diverse". Yes, that's their idea of diversity. Help out for 30 minutes in a poor community and then make sure you have a good time at your restaurant & bar only the top 1% of the population can afford.
advice_to_mgmt: What management?

GitHub has evolved considerably over the past year. From solidifying its vision, to exponentially expanding its B2B market presence, to an eventual acquisition by Microsoft. With regards to growth potential, the future has never been brighter. 

My experience at GitHub has been overwhelmingly positive, and the growth opportunities are abundant. With excellent leadership, numerous development opportunities, and a top-of-the-line benefits package, I can confidently say that I love my job.
